natural problem: A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
natural solution: Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
$\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.

We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> (a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a))"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. (\<exists> j. j \<in> {4, 5, 6, .., n} \<and> i = j) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k \<in> {4, 5, 6, .., n} \<and> i + 1 = k)"
shows  "n \<le> 253"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> (a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a))"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. (\<exists> j. j \<in> {4, 5, 6, .., n} \<and> i = j) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k \<in> {4, 5, 6, .., n} \<and> i + 1 = k)"
shows  "n \<le> 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A set S contains 10 unique natural numbers such that for any three distinct numbers a, b, and c from the set, the sum of any two of these numbers is greater than the third number (i.e., they form a triangle). All numbers in S are consecutive and belong to the range from 4 to n. Find the largest possible value of n. The final answer is 253.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and triangle_property :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "triangle_property S \<longleftrightarrow> (\<exists>a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
and h1 : "\<forall>S. S \<subseteq> {4..n} \<and> card S = 10 \<longrightarrow> triangle_property S"
shows  "n = 253"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and triangle_property :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "triangle_property S \<longleftrightarrow> (\<exists>a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
and h1 : "\<forall>S. S \<subseteq> {4..n} \<and> card S = 10 \<longrightarrow> triangle_property S"
shows  "n = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given any set of 10 distinct natural numbers from the range $4$ to $n$, there always exists a combination of three numbers within the set that form a valid triangle. What is the largest possible value of $n$? The final answer is $253$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {4, 5, 6,.., n}"
and h1 : "\<forall>A. A \<subseteq> S \<and> card A = 10 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> c \<in> A \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "n = 253"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {4, 5, 6,.., n}"
and h1 : "\<forall>A. A \<subseteq> S \<and> card A = 10 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> c \<in> A \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "n = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a set S containing consecutive natural numbers starting from 4 and ending with n, every subset A of S with 10 elements has at least one combination of three distinct elements a, b, and c from A such that they form a triangle (a + b > c, a + c > b, and b + c > a). Find the value of n. The final answer is 253.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
and h1 : "{4, 5, 6, ..., n} ⊆ S"
shows  "n = 253"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
and h1 : "{4, 5, 6, ..., n} ⊆ S"
shows  "n = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A set $S$ contains 10 distinct natural numbers such that for any three distinct numbers $a$, $b$, and $c$ in $S$, the sum of any two of them is greater than the third. If the set contains the consecutive numbers from 4 to $n$, find the value of $n$. The final answer is 253.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {4..n}"
and h1 : "card S = n - 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> T. card T = 10 \<and> T \<subseteq> S \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c. a \<in> T \<and> b \<in> T \<and> c \<in> T \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "n = 253"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {4..n}"
and h1 : "card S = n - 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> T. card T = 10 \<and> T \<subseteq> S \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c. a \<in> T \<and> b \<in> T \<and> c \<in> T \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "n = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a set S of consecutive integers from 4 to n, every subset T of S with 10 elements has at least one triple of distinct elements a, b, and c such that a + b > c, a + c > b, and b + c > a. Find the largest possible value of n. The final answer is 253.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set" and T :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {4, 5, 6, .., n}"
and h1 : "finite S"
and h2 : "card T = 10"
and h3 : "T \<subseteq> S"
and h4 : "\<forall> a b c. {a, b, c} \<subseteq> T \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> triangle a b c"
shows  "n \<le> 253"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set" and T :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {4, 5, 6, .., n}"
and h1 : "finite S"
and h2 : "card T = 10"
and h3 : "T \<subseteq> S"
and h4 : "\<forall> a b c. {a, b, c} \<subseteq> T \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> triangle a b c"
shows  "n \<le> 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Suppose a set $S$ consists of consecutive integers from $4$ to $n$, and a subset $T$ of $S$ has $10$ distinct elements. If any three distinct elements of $T$ form a triangle, what is the largest possible value of $n$? The final answer is $253$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> S. 4 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> n) \<longrightarrow>
                (\<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and>
                          a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and>
                          a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "n \<le> 253"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> S. 4 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> n) \<longrightarrow>
                (\<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and>
                          a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and>
                          a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "n \<le> 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given an integer $n \geq 4$, prove that for every set $S$ of 10 distinct integers between 4 and $n$, inclusive, there exist three distinct integers $a, b, c$ in $S$ such that $a + b > c$, $a + c > b$, and $b + c > a$. Furthermore, show that $n$ must be less than or equal to 253.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and A :: "nat set" and T :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "A = {4..n}"
and h1 : "T B \<longleftrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c. a \<in> B \<and> b \<in> B \<and> c \<in> B \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> triangle_property a b c)"
and h2 : "\<forall> B. B \<subseteq> A \<and> card B = 10 \<longrightarrow> T B"
shows  "n = 253"

where "triangle_property a b c \<equiv> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and A :: "nat set" and T :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "A = {4..n}"
and h1 : "T B \<longleftrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c. a \<in> B \<and> b \<in> B \<and> c \<in> B \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> triangle_property a b c)"
and h2 : "\<forall> B. B \<subseteq> A \<and> card B = 10 \<longrightarrow> T B"
shows  "n = 253"

where "triangle_property a b c \<equiv> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a set $A$ containing the consecutive natural numbers from $4$ to $n$, we define a set $B$ to have the triangle property if there exist three distinct elements $a$, $b$, and $c$ in $B$ such that they satisfy the triangle inequality: $a + b > c$, $a + c > b$, and $b + c > a$. If every subset $B$ of $A$ with exactly $10$ elements has the triangle property, find the value of $n$. The final answer is $253$.

theorem
fixes n :: nat and triangle_property :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> S. S \<subseteq> {4, 5, 6, ..., n} \<and> card S = 10 \<longrightarrow> triangle_property S"
shows  "n = 253"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.

fixes n :: nat and triangle_property :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> S. S \<subseteq> {4, 5, 6, ..., n} \<and> card S = 10 \<longrightarrow> triangle_property S"
shows  "n = 253"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and triangle_property :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> triangle_property {a, b, c}) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> x \<in> S. 4 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> n)"
shows  "n = 253"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A set of positive numbers has the triangle property if it has three distinct elements that are the lengths of the sides of a triangle whose area is positive. Consider sets $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, n\}$ of consecutive positive integers, all of whose ten-element subsets have the triangle property. What is the largest possible value of $n$?
 The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Out of all ten-element subsets with distinct elements that do not possess the triangle property, we want to find the one with the smallest maximum element. Call this subset $\mathcal{S}$. Without loss of generality, consider any $a, b, c \,\in \mathcal{S}$ with $a < b < c$.
 $\,\mathcal{S}$ does not possess the triangle property, so $c \geq a + b$.
 We use this property to build up $\mathcal{S}$ from the smallest possible $a$ and $b$: \[\mathcal{S} = \{\, 4,\, 5,\, 4+5, \,5+(4+5),\, \ldots\,\} = \{4, 5, 9, 14, 23, 37, 60, 97, 157, 254\}\] $\mathcal{S}$ is the "smallest" ten-element subset without the triangle property, and since the set $\{4, 5, 6, \ldots, 253\}$ is the largest set of consecutive integers that does not contain this subset, it is also the largest set of consecutive integers in which all ten-element subsets possess the triangle property.
 Thus, our answer is $n = \boxed{253}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and triangle_property :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> S. card S = 10 \<and> (\<forall> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> triangle_property {a, b, c}) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> x \<in> S. 4 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> n)"
shows  "n = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a set of 10 distinct natural numbers, where any combination of 3 distinct numbers from the set forms a triangle with some property, find the maximum possible value for the largest number in the set. The final answer is 253.
